text: Standard 1: Numbers and Operations: NUMBER SENSE—Understand numbers, ways of representing numbers, relationships among numbers, and number systems

children.text: NUMBERS AND NUMBER SYSTEMS
Count and compare groups of objects up to 30 according to the number of objects in each group
Represent whole numbers up to 30 in flexible ways (e.g., relating, composing, and decomposing numbers)
Count whole numbers up to 100 in a variety of ways (e.g., skip counts by 2's, 5's, 10's)
Identify representations of simple fractions (e.g., onehalf, one-third, one fourth)
Represent whole numbers up to 100 in flexible ways (e.g., relating, composing, and decomposing numbers), including the use of tens as a unit
Represent whole numbers up to 1000 in flexible ways (e.g., relating, composing, and decomposing numbers), including the use of tens and hundreds as units
Compare whole numbers up to 1000 using words (e.g., greater than, less than, equal to)
Represent fractions with denominators no larger than ten using pictures, numbers, words, or models
Represent place value from hundredths to ten-thousands flexibly
Categorize and justify a number as being odd or even
Compare and order fractions with denominators up to 12 (e.g., greater than, less than, equal)
Use fractions with denominators up to 12 to solve problems
Identify place value from ten-thousandths to millions
Identify and list factors, multiples, prime numbers, and composite numbers
Identify equivalent forms of commonly used fractions and decimals
Represent percent and ratio using pictures or objects
Use equivalent forms of whole numbers, fractions, ratios, decimals, and percents to solve problems
Use models, benchmarks, and equivalent forms to judge the size of fractions and order them
Compare and order fractions, decimals, and percents
Explain and give examples of number theory concepts (e.g., prime factorization, common factors, greatest common factor, common multiples, least common multiple, divisibility)
Solve problems using fractions, decimals, and percents
Identify situations that require the use of large numbers and represent them using scientific notation
Describe and solve situations represented by integers and absolute value
Apply number theory concepts to solve problems
Identify situations represented by square roots and cube roots
Compare and order rational numbers and square roots
Use ratios and proportions to represent the relationship between two quantities

text: Standard 2: Numbers and Operations: OPERATION SENSE—Understand the meaning of operations and how they relate to each other

children.text: OPERATIONS
Demonstrate addition as "putting together" or "combining sets"
Demonstrate subtraction as "taking away," "separating sets," or "counting back"
Demonstrate that addition and subtraction of whole numbers can undo each other
Recognize situations involving addition and subtraction and represent the situation with a number sentence
Demonstrate multiplication as repeated addition of equal groups
Demonstrate division as "separating equal groups"
Recognize situations involving multiplication and division of whole numbers and represent the situation with a number sentence
Select and apply various meanings and representations of multiplication and division
Demonstrate that multiplication and division of whole numbers can undo each other
Describe situations involving addition and subtraction of fractions and decimals
Apply the inverse relationship between addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, to solve problems
Describe situations involving multiplication and division of fractions and decimals
Apply the order of operations when calculating with whole numbers
Describe situations involving arithmetic operations with integers
Apply the order of operations when calculating with rational number, excluding exponents
Apply the inverse relationship between addition and subtraction, and between multiplication and division, to solve onestep equations
Apply the order of operations when calculating with rational numbers
Demonstrate the inverse relationship between square numbers and square roots, and cubes and cubed roots
OPERATION PROPERTIES
Use properties of addition of whole numbers (e.g., associative, commutative) to solve problems
Apply the properties of zero and one as they relate to addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division
Use the operation properties to simplify computations with fractions, decimals, and percents
PROPERTIES
Use associative, commutative, and distributive properties as they apply to operations involving whole numbers

text: Standard 3: Numbers and Operations: COMPUTATION STRATEGIES—Use computational tools and strategies fluently and, when appropriate, use estimation

children.text: COMPUTATIONAL FLUENCY
Use a variety of strategies (e.g., objects, fingers) to add and subtract single-digit whole numbers
Recall single-digit addition facts
Use a variety of strategies to solve number problems involving addition and subtraction (e.g., comparing sets, counting on, counting backwards, doubles, doubles plus one)
Recall addition facts and their corresponding subtraction facts up to twenty
Use a variety of strategies to solve problems involving addition and subtraction of two-digit numbers
Estimate the solution of addition and subtraction problems
Recall multiplication facts from 0 x 0 to 10 x 10
Use a variety of strategies to solve problems involving addition and subtraction of two- and three-digit numbers
Recall all multiplication facts and the corresponding division facts up to 12 x 12
Select and use appropriate strategies and/or tools (e.g., mental math, calculators, paper/pencil, standard algorithms) for computing whole numbers
Use a variety of strategies to add and subtract fractions with like and unlike denominators
Add and subtract decimals to 3 places
Multiply decimals up to 3 places and divide decimals by whole numbers
Use a variety of strategies to multiply and divide fractions
Add, subtract, multiply, and divide integers
Add, subtract, multiply, and divide numbers with whole number exponents
ESTIMATION
Estimate the results of whole-number computations
Determine the reasonableness of numerical solutions
Use estimation prior to computing with fractions and decimals and compare the estimation to the actual result
Recognize situations in which it is more appropriate to estimate than to compute an exact answer
Determine the reasonableness of a solution by comparing the answer to an estimate
Estimate a reasonable range (i.e., upper and lower limit) for the solution to a problem

text: Standard 4: Measurement: FLUENCY WITH MEASUREMENT—Understand attributes, units, and systems of units in measurement; and develop and use techniques, tools, and formulas for measuring

children.text: MEASUREMENT ATTRIBUTES AND UNITS
Compare and order objects according to length, weight, capacity, area, and volume
Identify the value of pennies, nickels, and dimes and the equivalence among them (e.g., 5 pennies = 1 nickel)
Tell time to the hour
Measure with multiple copies of standard (e.g., inch tiles, foot-long lengths of string) or non-standard (e.g., paper clips, pencils) units of the same size
Identify the value of coins and count coin combinations (using like coins) to a dollar
Tell time to the half-hour and quarter-hour
Measure length using inches, feet, and centimeters
Identify appropriate units for measuring length, area, capacity, and weight
Estimate and measure temperature using standard units (e.g., Fahrenheit, Celsius)
Tell time to the minute
Represent a given monetary amount using a variety of combinations of coins and bills
Describe the concept of area and volume and the appropriate units for each
Measure area and volume using standard and nonstandard units (e.g., tiles, index cards, grids, cubes)
Measure length, capacity, and weight in U.S. customary and metric units (e.g., pound, kilogram)
Estimate and determine the elapsed time between two events or times
Explain the need to use standard units for measuring
Select and apply appropriate customary and metric units and tools to measure length, perimeter, and area for the degree of accuracy needed
Classify right angles, acute angles, obtuse angles, and straight angles
Convert simple units within a system of measurement (e.g., millimeters to centimeters, feet to yard, quarts to gallons, gram to kilogram, minutes to hours, days to weeks)
Select and apply appropriate customary and metric units and tools to measure angles
Estimate the circumference and area of a circle (with no reference to a formula)
Construct angles with a given degree measure
Determine how measurements, such as perimeter and area, of common shapes (e.g., squares, rectangles, parallelograms, triangles, circles) are affected when one of the attributes is changed in some way
Select and use appropriate units to measure the surface area and volume of solids
MEASUREMENT TOOLS AND TECHNIQUES
Identify tools used to measure time (i.e., digital and analog clock, calendar)
Identify measurement tools that could be used to measure length, capacity, and weight
Identify objects or visual benchmarks that could be used in place of standard units when estimating
Select appropriate tools for measuring length, capacity, and weight
Estimate and measure perimeter and area of common shapes and irregular (e.g., a house-shaped pentagon) shapes
Estimate and measure surface area and volume using U.S. customary units and metric units
Use map scales to measure the distance between locations and make simple scale drawings
Estimate and measure the size of an angle
Uses ratios and proportions to relate a scale drawing to the actual object
Express rates of change as a ratio of two different measures, where units are included in the ratio, and use the derived rate to solve problems
MEASUREMENT FORMULAS
Use known measurements to calculate desired measurements of squares and rectangles (e.g., use the length of the square to calculate its area and perimeter)
Use known measurements (e.g., base and height) to calculate desired measurements (e.g., area) of triangles, parallelograms, and trapezoids
Use known measurements (e.g., length, width, and height) to calculate desired measurements (e.g., surface area and volume) of rectangular solids
Apply strategies and formulas to solve area and perimeter problems involving polygons (e.g., regular hexagons) and complex shapes (i.e., shapes composed of two or more common shapes)
Use known measurements (e.g., radius) to calculate desired measurements (e.g., circumference and area) of circles
Use ratios and proportions to solve measurement problems
Use formulas to determine the surface area and volume of selected prisms, cylinders, and pyramids

text: Standard 5: Geometry and Spatial Sense: PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS—Analyze properties of objects and relationships among the properties

children.text: GEOMETRIC SHAPES AND THEIR PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS
Identify common geometric shapes (e.g., circle, square, rectangle, triangle)
Identify basic three-dimensional geometric solids (e.g., cube, sphere, rectangular prism)
Identify attributes and parts of common two- and threedimensional shapes
Compare and sort two- and three-dimensional shapes according to selected attributes
Compare the basic properties of isosceles, equilateral, and right triangles
Classify shapes as congruent or similar
Classify different types of triangles and quadrilaterals according to their properties and identify the properties that define the classifications
Describe lines in the plane (i.e., parallel, perpendicular, intersecting)
Compare points, lines, line segments, and rays
Predict and confirm the results of putting together and taking apart two- and three-dimensional shapes
Describe the properties that define classifications of three-dimensional shapes (e.g., cylinders have two bases that are circles)
Apply the understanding that the sum of the measures of the angles in any triangle is 180°
Classify angles (no larger than 180°) as acute, right, obtuse, or straight
Analyze and describe the relationships among the angles, side lengths, perimeters, and areas of similar geometric figures
Create arguments for proving that two shapes are congruent
Apply the concept of similarity to solve problems
Apply the Pythagorean theorem to solve problems involving right triangles

text: Standard 6: Geometry and Spatial Sense: TRANSFORMATIONS AND SYMMETRY—Use transformations and symmetry to analyze mathematical situations

children.text: TRANSFORMATION
Use slides, flips, and turns to solve puzzles
Demonstrate flips, slides, and turns by moving shapes
Predict and confirm the result of flipping, sliding, and turning shapes
Use flips, slides, and turns to show that a shape or design is symmetrical
Use flips, slides, and turns to determine if two figures are congruent
Predict and confirm the results of combinations of flips, turns, and slides
Describe changes in size between a given figure and its dilation
Perform a transformation (reflection, rotation, translation) when given a figure and necessary parameters
Describe the size, position, and orientation of shapes under transformations and compositions of transformations
SYMMETRY
Identify symmetrical shapes found in the real world
Recognize line symmetry in plane figures and create pictures with line symmetry
Recognize rotational symmetry of plane figures
Locate the plane of symmetry in three-dimensional objects
Identify three-dimensional objects that have rotational symmetry and locate the rotational axis
Use line symmetry and rotational symmetry to describe classifications of shapes (e.g., squares have 4 lines of symmetry and 90° rotational symmetry)

text: Standard 7: Geometry and Spatial Sense: VISUAL AND SPATIAL SENSE—Use visualization and spatial reasoning to solve problems both within and outside of mathematics

children.text: VISUALIZATION AND SPATIAL REASONING
Predict the three-dimensional object that will result from folding a two-dimensional net of the object and justify the prediction
Use two-dimensional nets of rectangular solids to solve surface area problems
Construct a two-dimensional representation from different angles of a three-dimensional object
Draw two-dimensional shapes with specified properties
Use two-dimensional representations of pyramids, prisms, and cylinders to solve problems involving these figures

text: Standard 8: Geometry and Spatial Sense: REPRESENTATIONAL SYSTEMS—Select and use different representational systems, including coordinate geometry

children.text: COORDINATE GEOMETRY
Use positional words to describe an object's location (e.g., up, down, above, under, inside, outside)
Use directional words to locate an object or place (e.g., left, right, near, far)
Use cardinal directions that describe the location of an object or place (i.e., north, south, east, or west) on a coordinate map
Use coordinates to locate objects/locations on a grid
Use ordered pairs to plot points on a coordinate grid
Determine the distance between points along horizontal and vertical lines of a coordinate system
Predict the shape that is formed by connecting the points represented by given coordinates
Use coordinate geometry to represent and analyze properties of geometric shapes
Use coordinate geometry to determine the change in size of a figure that is dilated by a scale factor
Use coordinate geometry to represent transformations in the coordinate plane

text: Standard 9: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: PATTERNS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS—Understand various types of patterns and functional relationships

children.text: PATTERNS
Demonstrate repeating patterns involving shapes, objects, sounds, and movements
Extend, create, and describe repeating patterns
Describe and create addition and subtraction number patterns (e.g., [20, 17, 14, …] )
Use different forms (e.g., concrete, pictorial, numerical) to represent the same basic pattern
Demonstrate and explain the difference between repeating patterns and growing patterns
Create and describe growing numerical and spatial patterns and generalize a rule for the pattern
Use patterns to solve problem situations involving related quantities in which one quantity changes as the other changes
Identify and describe patterns in a hundreds chart
Extend, create, and generalize growing and shrinking numeric and geometric patterns (including multiplication patterns)
Analyze patterns and functions and use generalizations to make reasonable predictions
Represent visual and numerical patterns with tables and graphs and generalize the "rule" using words and symbols
Create a pattern or function for a rule given in symbolic form
Represent a variety of patterns (including recursive patterns) with tables, graphs (including graphing technology when available), words, and when possible, symbolic rules
FUNCTION
Represent the relationship between quantities in a variety of forms (e.g., manipulatives, tables, pictures, symbols)
Describe situations in which the relationship between two quantities vary directly or inversely
Describe simple one-step functions using words and symbols when given a table of "input" and "output" values
Describe multi-step functions using words and symbols when given a table of "input" and "output" values and use the rule for the function to determine other input and output values
Use linear relationships with two variables to solve problems
Identify functions as linear or nonlinear and contrast their properties from tables, graphs (including graphing technology when available), or equations

text: Standard 10: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: SYMBOLIC REPRESENTATION—Use symbolic forms to represent, model, and analyze mathematical situations

children.text: NUMERIC AND ALGEBRAIC REPRESENTATIONS
Represent simple numerical situations with objects and number sentences
Use objects, pictures, words, and number sentences to represent and solve numerical problem situations involving addition and subtraction
Create a word/story problem for a given number sentence
Model situations that involve multiplication and division of whole numbers using objects/pictures and number sentences
Use symbols to represent unknown quantities in open sentences and determine the unknown quantities
Represent the commutative, associative, and distributive properties symbolically
Use a variety of strategies to solve number sentences with unknowns
Model problem situations with objects or manipulatives and use representations (e.g., graphs, tables, equations) to draw conclusions
Interpret and solve problem situations involving two different variables
Use fact families to solve for an unknown in an open sentence
Evaluate algebraic expressions
Analyze the relationship among tables, graphs (including graphing technology when available), and equations of linear functions, paying particular attention to the meaning of intercept and slope
Use symbolic algebra to represent situations involving linear relationships
Solves linear equations and inequalities with one variable using algebraic methods, manipulatives, or models
Translate among tables, graphs (including graphing technology when available), and equations involving linear relationships
Solve linear equations and inequalities with two variables using algebraic methods, manipulatives, or models
Use tables and graphs to represent and compare linear relationships
RATES OF CHANGE
Identify situations involving change and describe the change numerically and verbally
Describe the rate of change numerically and verbally based on data recorded in a table or graph
Describe situations with constant or varying rates (e.g., miles per hour, items per box)
Use the slope of a line to describe a constant rate of change

text: Standard 11: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: FLUENCY WITH DATA—Pose questions and collect, organize, and represent data to answer those questions

children.text: DATA COLLECTION AND REPRESENTATION
Sort objects or people according to stated attributes
Collect and organize information using concrete objects and pictures
Pose questions, collect data, and display the data using a graph (e.g., bar graphs, pictographs)
Pose questions, collect data using surveys, and organize the data into tables and graphs
Organize and represent data in more than one way (e.g., tallies, chart, tables, bar graphs, line plots, line graphs)
Pose questions, collect data using observations and experiments, and organize the data into tables or graphs
Label the parts of a graph (e.g., axes, scale, legend, title)
Collect and display data in circle graphs
Recognize the difference in representing numeric data and categorical data and select appropriate representations to display each type of data
Analyze how data collection methods and sample size can affect the results of data sets
Design a study, collect data, and select the appropriate representation (line graph, bar graph, circle graph, histogram, stem and leaf plot, box and whisker plot) to display the data

Design a study that compares two samples, collect data, and select the appropriate representation (e.g., double bar graph, back-to-back stem and leaf plot, parallel box and whisker plots, scatter plot) to compare the sets of data
Judge the validity of data based on the data collection method

text: Standard 12: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: STATISTICS—Interpret data using methods of exploratory data analysis

children.text: DATA INTERPRETATION
Interpret data using simple language (e.g., more, less, fewer, equal)
Interpret data displayed in a bar graph and describe how the important features of the data set are represented in a bar graph
Interpret data (e.g., tallies, chart, tables, bar graphs, line plots) and state what the representation shows about the set of data
Compare related data sets (e.g., height of 4th grade boys vs. height of 4th grade girls) with an emphasis on how the data are distributed
Analyze important features in the shape of the graph of a data set
Determine the range, median, mode, and mean for a data set
Compare different representations of the same data and evaluate how well each representation shows important aspects of the data
Determine and interpret the measures of center (mean, median, mode) of a data set and explain what each measure indicates about the data set
Use a stem-and-leaf plot to analyze a set of data
Relate the spread of a data set to a box-and-whisker plot
Recognize situations appropriate for scatter plots
Analyze different representations of the same data to describe how representations can be used to skew a person's interpretation of the data

text: Standard 13: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: DATA ANALYSIS—Develop and evaluate inferences, predictions, and arguments that are based on data

children.text: PREDICTIONS AND INFERENCES
Answer questions based on data represented in graphs
Propose and justify conclusions/predictions based on data
Design studies to further investigate the conclusion/predictions made based on data
Make inferences about a population based on the interpretation of a sample data set
Formulate new questions that arise from previous conclusions or conjectures and plan a new study to answer them
Make conjectures about possible relationships between two characteristics of a sample based on interpretations of scatter plots

text: Standard 14: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: PROBABILITY—Understand and apply basic notions of chance and probability

children.text: PROBABILITY
Make reasonable predictions concerning the likelihood of an event occurring (e.g., certain, likely, unlikely, impossible)
Predict the probability of outcomes of simple experiments (e.g., coin toss, 4-colored spinner) and test the predictions
Use fractions, decimals, and percents to indicate the probability of events
Determine all possible outcomes of a simple compound event
Compute probabilities of simple compound events (e.g., rolling two dice, using two different spinners at the same time)
Relate theoretical probability to experimental results
Judge the validity of conjectures that are based on experiments or simulations

text: Pre-Algebra

children.text: Standard 1: Numbers and Operations: NUMBER SENSE—Understand numbers, ways of representing numbers, relationships among numbers, and number systems
NUMBERS AND NUMBER SYSTEMS
Identify situations represented by square roots and cube roots
Compare and order rational numbers and square roots
Use ratios and proportions to represent the relationship between two quantities
Standard 2: Numbers and Operations: OPERATION SENSE—Understand the meaning of operations and how they relate to each other
OPERATIONS
Apply the order of operations when calculating with rational numbers
Demonstrate the inverse relationship between square numbers and square roots, and cubes and cubed roots
Standard 3: Numbers and Operations: COMPUTATION STRATEGIES—Use computational tools and strategies fluently and, when appropriate, use estimation
COMPUTATIONAL FLUENCY
Add, subtract, multiply, and divide numbers with whole number exponents
ESTIMATION
Estimate a reasonable range (i.e., upper and lower limit) for the solution to a problem
Explain that rounding answers in certain real-world situations may lead to major problems
Standard 4: Measurement: FLUENCY WITH MEASUREMENT—Understand attributes, units, and systems of units in measurement; and develop and use techniques, tools, and formulas for measuring
MEASUREMENT ATTRIBUTES AND UNITS
Select and use appropriate units to measure the surface area and volume of solids
MEASUREMENT TOOLS AND TECHNIQUES
Express rates of change as a ratio of two different measures, where units are included in the ratio, and use the derived rate to solve problems
MEASUREMENT FORMULAS
Use ratios and proportions to solve measurement problems
Use formulas to determine the surface area and volume of selected prisms, cylinders, and pyramids
Use the right triangle relationships (e.g., trigonometric ratios: cosine, sine, and tangent) to solve problems
Standard 5: Geometry and Spatial Sense: PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS—Analyze properties of objects and relationships among the properties
GEOMETRIC SHAPES AND THEIR PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS
Apply the Pythagorean theorem to solve problems involving right triangles
Evaluate conjectures about classes of two- and threedimensional shapes/objects
Standard 6: Geometry and Spatial Sense: TRANSFORMATIONS AND SYMMETRY—Use transformations and symmetry to analyze mathematical situations
TRANSFORMATION
Perform a transformation (reflection, rotation, translation) when given a figure and necessary parameters
Describe the size, position, and orientation of shapes under transformations and compositions of transformations
Describe three-dimensional shapes that are formed by rotating two-dimensional figures about an axis
Standard 7: Geometry and Spatial Sense: VISUAL AND SPATIAL SENSE—Use visualization and spatial reasoning to solve problems both within and outside of mathematics
VISUALIZATION AND SPATIAL REASONING
Use two-dimensional representations of pyramids, prisms, and cylinders to solve problems involving these figures
Standard 8: Geometry and Spatial Sense: REPRESENTATIONAL SYSTEMS—Select and use different representational systems, including coordinate geometry
COORDINATE GEOMETRY
Use coordinate geometry to represent transformations in the coordinate plane
Standard 9: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: PATTERNS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS—Understand various types of patterns and functional relationships
PATTERNS
Represent a variety of patterns (including recursive patterns) with tables, graphs (including graphing technology when available), words, and when possible, symbolic rules
FUNCTIONS
Use linear relationships with two variables to solve problems
Identify functions as linear or nonlinear and contrast their properties from tables, graphs (including graphing technology when available), or equations
Standard 10: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: SYMBOLIC REPRESENTATION—Use symbolic forms to represent, model, and analyze mathematical situations
NUMERIC AND ALGEBRAIC REPRESENTATIONS
Translate among tables, graphs (including graphing technology when available), and equations involving linear relationships
Solve linear equations and inequalities with two variables using algebraic methods, manipulatives, or models
Use tables and graphs to represent and compare linear relationships
RATES OF CHANGE
Use the slope of a line to describe a constant rate of change
Standard 11: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: FLUENCY WITH DATA—Pose questions and collect, organize, and represent data to answer those questions
DATA COLLECTION AND REPRESENTATION

Design a study that compares two samples, collect data, and select the appropriate representation (double bar graph, back-to-back stem and leaf plot, parallel box and whisker plots, scatter plot) to compare the sets of data
Judge the validity of data based on the data collection method
Standard 12: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: STATISTICS—Interpret data using methods of exploratory data analysis
DATA INTERPRETATION
Recognize situations appropriate for scatter plots
Analyze different representations of the same data to describe how representations can be used to skew a person's interpretation of the data
Standard 13: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: DATA ANALYSIS—Develop and evaluate inferences, predictions, and arguments that are based on data
PREDICTIONS AND INFERENCES
Make conjectures about possible relationships between two characteristics of a sample based on interpretations of scatter plots
Standard 14: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: PROBABILITY—Understand and apply basic notions of chance and probability
PROBABILITY
Judge the validity of conjectures that are based on experiments or simulations
Calculate probabilities for simple events under different relationships (e.g., inclusion, disjoint, complementary, independent, dependent, with replacement, without replacement)
Use the fundamental counting principle to calculate combinations and permutations

text: Algebra I

children.text: Standard 1: Numbers and Operations: NUMBER SENSE—Understand numbers, ways of representing numbers, relationships among numbers, and number systems
NUMBERS AND NUMBER SYSTEMS
Recognize situations that can be represented by matrices
Standard 2: Numbers and Operations: OPERATION SENSE—Understand the meaning of operations and how they relate to each other
Standard 3: Numbers and Operations: COMPUTATION STRATEGIES—Use computational tools and strategies fluently and, when appropriate, use estimation
COMPUTATIONAL FLUENCY
Apply arithmetic properties to operate on and simplify expressions that include radicals and other real numbers
Apply the laws of exponents to perform operations on expressions with integral exponents
Use addition, subtraction, and scalar multiplication of matrices to solve problems
Standard 4: Measurement: FLUENCY WITH MEASUREMENT—Understand attributes, units, and systems of units in measurement; and develop and use techniques, tools, and formulas for measuring
MEASUREMENT FORMULAS
Use formulas, functions, or conversion equations to solve problems dealing with determining a measurement based on another derived or given measurement
Standard 5: Geometry and Spatial Sense: PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS—Analyze properties of objects and relationships among the properties
Standard 6: Geometry and Spatial Sense: TRANSFORMATIONS AND SYMMETRY—Use transformations and symmetry to analyze mathematical situations
Standard 7: Geometry and Spatial Sense: VISUAL AND SPATIAL SENSE—Use visualization and spatial reasoning to solve problems both within and outside of mathematics
Standard 8: Geometry and Spatial Sense: REPRESENTATIONAL SYSTEMS—Select and use different representational systems, including coordinate geometry
COORDINATE GEOMETRY
Graph linear equations using slope-intercept, pointslope, and x- and y-intercept techniques
Determine the slope of a line when given the graph of a line, two points on the line, or the equation of the line
Standard 9: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: PATTERNS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS—Understand various types of patterns and functional relationships
PATTERNS
Determine if a linear pattern exists in a set of data and represent the data algebraically and graphically
Compare and contrast the concepts of direct and inverse variation of a relation
FUNCTIONS
Determine the zeros of a linear or quadratic function algebraically and graphically
Compare and contrast the properties of linear functions and exponential functions
Standard 10: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: SYMBOLIC REPRESENTATION—Use symbolic forms to represent, model, and analyze mathematical situations
NUMERIC AND ALGEBRAIC REPRESENTATIONS
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable using a variety of strategies (e.g., algebraically, by graphing, by using a graphing calculator)
Translate between verbal mathematical situations and algebraic expressions and equations
Justify the steps used in simplifying expressions and solving equations and inequalities
Determine the equation of a line when given the graph of the line, the slope and a point on the line, or two points on the line
Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically and graphically
Factor first- and second-degree binomials and trinomials in one or two variables
Solve quadratic equations in one variable algebraically, graphically, or by using graphing technology
Select and use a variety of strategies (e.g., concrete objects, pictorial representations, algebraic manipulation) to perform operations on polynomials
Analyze transformations of lines and understand how the transformation are represented in equations
Standard 11: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: FLUENCY WITH DATA—Pose questions and collect, organize, and represent data to answer those questions
Standard 12: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: STATISTICS—Interpret data using methods of exploratory data analysis
DATA INTERPRETATION
Compare data sets using statistical techniques (e.g., measures of central tendency, standard deviation, range, stem-andleaf plots, and box-and-whisker graphs)
Display bivariate data in a scatter plot, describe its shape, and determine the line of best fit that models a trend (if a trend exists)
Standard 13: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: DATA ANALYSIS—Develop and evaluate inferences, predictions, and arguments that are based on data
Standard 14: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: PROBABILITY—Understand and apply basic notions of chance and probability

text: Algebra II

children.text: Standard 1: Numbers and Operations: NUMBER SENSE—Understand numbers, ways of representing numbers, relationships among numbers, and number systems
NUMBERS AND NUMBER SYSTEMS
Use the complex number system, the notation for complex numbers, and the definition of "i" to solve problems
Standard 2: Numbers and Operations: OPERATION SENSE—Understand the meaning of operations and how they relate to each other
OPERATION PROPERTIES
Add, subtract, multiply, and divide complex numbers
Use the inverse relationship between exponents and logarithms to solve exponential and logarithmic problems
Standard 3: Numbers and Operations: COMPUTATION STRATEGIES—Use computational tools and strategies fluently and, when appropriate, use estimation
COMPUTATIONAL FLUENCY
Use matrix operations (i.e. multiplication and inverse) to solve problems
Standard 4: Measurement: FLUENCY WITH MEASUREMENT—Understand attributes, units, and systems of units in measurement; and develop and use techniques, tools, and formulas for measuring
MEASUREMENT FORMULAS
Use advanced formulas or functions to solve problems dealing with determining a measurement based on another derived or given measure
Standard 5: Geometry and Spatial Sense: PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS—Analyze properties of objects and relationships among the properties
Standard 6: Geometry and Spatial Sense: TRANSFORMATIONS AND SYMMETRY—Use transformations and symmetry to analyze mathematical situations
Standard 7: Geometry and Spatial Sense: VISUAL AND SPATIAL SENSE—Use visualization and spatial reasoning to solve problems both within and outside of mathematics
Standard 8: Geometry and Spatial Sense: REPRESENTATIONAL SYSTEMS—Select and use different representational systems, including coordinate geometry
Standard 9: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: PATTERNS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS—Understand various types of patterns and functional relationships
PATTERNS
Apply the properties of arithmetic and geometric sequences and series to solve problems
FUNCTION
Use exponential functions to solve problems involving exponential growth and decay
Use the properties of many types of functions (e.g., polynomial, step, absolute value, step, exponential, and logarithmic) to identify the function's graph
Use the appropriate terminology and notation to define functions and their properties (e.g., domain, range, function composition, inverses, zeros)
Determine the zeros of a function algebraically or graphically
Describe the relationship among relations and functions
Determine the domain and range of a relation given a graph or a set of points
Standard 10: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: SYMBOLIC REPRESENTATION—Use symbolic forms to represent, model, and analyze mathematical situations
NUMERIC AND ALGEBRAIC REPRESENTATIONS
Solve equations and inequalities involving absolute values
Solve systems of linear equations and inequalities in two or three variables using a variety of strategies (e.g., substitution, graphing, matrices, technology)
Solve equations containing radical and exponents
Factor polynomials representing perfect squares, the difference in squares, perfect square trinomials, the sum and difference of cubes, and general trinomials
Apply quadratic equations to real-world situations
Solve quadratic equations in the complex number system
Use the binomial theorem to expand binomial expression
Add, subtract, multiply, divide, and simplify rational expressions, radical expressions containing positive rational numbers, and expressions containing rational exponents
Translate between the equations of conic sections (e.g., circle, ellipse, parabola, hyperbola) and their graphs
Analyze translations and dilations for graphs of absolute value functions, parabolas, and circles, and understand how the transformations are represented in equations
Standard 11: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: FLUENCY WITH DATA—Pose questions and collect, organize, and represent data to answer those questions
Standard 12: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: STATISTICS—Interpret data using methods of exploratory data analysis
DATA INTERPRETATION
Identify trends in bivariate data and find functions that model the data
Standard 13: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: DATA ANALYSIS—Develop and evaluate inferences, predictions, and arguments that are based on data
Standard 14: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: PROBABILITY—Understand and apply basic notions of chance and probability
PROBABILITY
Use the fundamental counting principles for combinations and permutations to determine probability
Calculate probabilities of events under different relationships (e.g., inclusion, disjoint, complementary, independent, dependent, with replacement, without replacement)

text: Geometry

children.text: Standard 1: Numbers and Operations: NUMBER SENSE—Understand numbers, ways of representing numbers, relationships among numbers, and number systems
VECTORS
Recognize situations that can be represented by vectors
Standard 2: Numbers and Operations: OPERATION SENSE—Understand the meaning of operations and how they relate to each other
Standard 3: Numbers and Operations: COMPUTATION STRATEGIES—Use computational tools and strategies fluently and, when appropriate, use estimation
VECTORS
Use vector addition, subtraction, and scalar multiplication to solve problems
Standard 4: Measurement: FLUENCY WITH MEASUREMENT—Understand attributes, units, and systems of units in measurement; and develop and use techniques, tools, and formulas for measuring
MEASUREMENT FORMULAS
Use right triangle trigonometric ratios to solve for an unknown length of a side or the measure or an angle
Solve problems using the formulas for perimeter, circumference, area, and volume of two- and three- dimensional figures and solids
Determine the effect of dimension changes to perimeter, area, and volume for common geometric figures and solids
Standard 5: Geometry and Spatial Sense: PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS—Analyze properties of objects and relationships among the properties
GEOMETRIC SHAPES AND THEIR PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS
Use inductive and deductive reasoning to create and defend geometric conjectures
Use the concept of corresponding parts to prove that triangles, and other polygons, are congruent or similar
Explain properties and characteristics of angle bisectors, perpendicular bisectors, and parallel lines
Use the relationship between pairs of angles (e.g., complementary, supplementary, vertical, exterior, interior) to determine unknown angle measures or definitions of properties
Apply the concepts of special right triangles to realworld situations
Use the relationships among properties of circles (e.g., chords, secants, tangents, arcs, circumference, radius, diameter, inscribed polygons) to solve problems
Standard 6: Geometry and Spatial Sense: TRANSFORMATIONS AND SYMMETRY—Use transformations and symmetry to analyze mathematical situations
TRANSFORMATION
Describe three-dimensional figures that are formed by translating two-dimensional figures
Standard 7: Geometry and Spatial Sense: VISUAL AND SPATIAL SENSE—Use visualization and spatial reasoning to solve problems both within and outside of mathematics
VISUALIZATION AND SPATIAL REASONING
Draw cross-sections, truncations, and compositions/decompositions of three-dimensional objects
GEOMETRIC MODELING
Use concrete objects, pictorial representations, computer software, or graphing calculators to solve geometric problems
Standard 8: Geometry and Spatial Sense: REPRESENTATIONAL SYSTEMS—Select and use different representational systems, including coordinate geometry
COORDINATE GEOMETRY
Use coordinate geometry to produce formulas and prove theorems for the midpoint of a line segment, the distance formula, and forms of equations of lines and circles
Describe the concept of rigid motion on figures in the coordinate plane, including rotation, translation, and reflection
Standard 9: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: PATTERNS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS—Understand various types of patterns and functional relationships
Standard 10: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: SYMBOLIC REPRESENTATION—Use symbolic forms to represent, model, and analyze mathematical situations
Standard 11: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: FLUENCY WITH DATA—Pose questions and collect, organize, and represent data to answer those questions
Standard 12: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: STATISTICS—Interpret data using methods of exploratory data analysis
Standard 13: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: DATA ANALYSIS—Develop and evaluate inferences, predictions, and arguments that are based on data
Standard 14: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: PROBABILITY—Understand and apply basic notions of chance and probability

text: Trigonometry

children.text: Standard 1: Numbers and Operations: NUMBER SENSE—Understand numbers, ways of representing numbers, relationships among numbers, and number systems
NUMBERS AND NUMBER SYSTEMS
Express complex numbers in standard and polar form, and convert from one to another
Standard 2: Numbers and Operations: OPERATION SENSE—Understand the meaning of operations and how they relate to each other
OPERATIONS
Add, subtract, multiply, divide, and find powers of complex numbers in polar form
Standard 3: Numbers and Operations: COMPUTATION STRATEGIES—Use computational tools and strategies fluently and, when appropriate, use estimation
VECTORS
Use vector operations, the law of sines, and the law of cosines to solve problems
Standard 4: Measurement: FLUENCY WITH MEASUREMENT—Understand attributes, units, and systems of units in measurement; and develop and use techniques, tools, and formulas for measuring
MEASUREMENT FORMULAS
Calculate linear and angular velocity
Standard 5: Geometry and Spatial Sense: PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS—Analyze properties of objects and relationships among the properties
GEOMETRIC SHAPES AND THEIR PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS
Find the sine, cosine, tangent, cotangent, secant, and cosecant of an angle in standard position
Use the relationship among the six trigonometric functions to translate among them (i.e., know that given one of the functions the value of the other five can be found)
Recognize the trigonometric functions of benchmark angles (e.g., 0, p/2, p, 3p/2)
Translate between radians and degrees
Find the value of any trigonometric function and inverse trigonometric function, and solve trigonometric equations
Use the fundamental trigonometric identities, including the sum and difference formulas, double-angle formulas, and halfangle formulas to solve problems
Verify trigonometric identities
Solve trigonometric equations and inverse trigonometric equations that include all solutions or solutions with restricted domains
Standard 6: Geometry and Spatial Sense: TRANSFORMATIONS AND SYMMETRY—Use transformations and symmetry to analyze mathematical situations
Standard 7: Geometry and Spatial Sense: VISUAL AND SPATIAL SENSE—Use visualization and spatial reasoning to solve problems both within and outside of mathematics
Standard 8: Geometry and Spatial Sense: REPRESENTATIONAL SYSTEMS—Select and use different representational systems, including coordinate geometry
Standard 9: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: PATTERNS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS—Understand various types of patterns and functional relationships
FUNCTION
Use the trigonometric functions in the form y = ASin (Bx+C) + D to determine various properties of the function (e.g., domain, range, period, phase shift, amplitude )
Identify real-world phenomena that can be represented by a trigonometric function in the form y = ASin(Bx + C) + D
Explain the relationship between trigonometric functions and their inverse
Standard 10: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: SYMBOLIC REPRESENTATION—Use symbolic forms to represent, model, and analyze mathematical situations
Standard 11: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: FLUENCY WITH DATA—Pose questions and collect, organize, and represent data to answer those questions
Standard 12: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: STATISTICS—Interpret data using methods of exploratory data analysis
Standard 13: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: DATA ANALYSIS—Develop and evaluate inferences, predictions, and arguments that are based on data
Standard 14: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: PROBABILITY—Understand and apply basic notions of chance and probability

text: Analytical Geometry

children.text: Standard 1: Numbers and Operations: NUMBER SENSE—Understand numbers, ways of representing numbers, relationships among numbers, and number systems
Standard 2: Numbers and Operations: OPERATION SENSE—Understand the meaning of operations and how they relate to each other
OPERATIONS
Use the sum, difference, scalar multiplication, dot product, and cross product of vectors to solve problems
Standard 3: Numbers and Operations: COMPUTATION STRATEGIES—Use computational tools and strategies fluently and, when appropriate, use estimation
Standard 4: Measurement: FLUENCY WITH MEASUREMENT—Understand attributes, units, and systems of units in measurement; and develop and use techniques, tools, and formulas for measuring
Standard 5: Geometry and Spatial Sense: PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS—Analyze properties of objects and relationships among the properties
Standard 6: Geometry and Spatial Sense: TRANSFORMATIONS AND SYMMETRY—Use transformations and symmetry to analyze mathematical situations
Standard 7: Geometry and Spatial Sense: VISUAL AND SPATIAL SENSE—Use visualization and spatial reasoning to solve problems both within and outside of mathematics
VISUALIZATION AND SPATIAL REASONING
Recognize conic sections and describe their characteristics
Standard 8: Geometry and Spatial Sense: REPRESENTATIONAL SYSTEMS—Select and use different representational systems, including coordinate geometry
COORDINATE GEOMETRY
Use formulas involving division of a line segment and angles between two lines
Use the relationship between the slope of a line and the angle of inclination to solve problems
Use the polar coordinate system to graph
Use the relationship between polar and rectangular form to convert back and forth
Standard 9: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: PATTERNS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS—Understand various types of patterns and functional relationships
GEOMETRIC SHAPES AND THEIR PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS

Use the relationship among the properties of conic sections (e.g., asymptotes, center of a conic, directrix, eccentricity, focus, major and minor axis, vertex) and graph conic sections using the standard form of the equations
Use properties (e.g., domain, range, intercepts, symmetry, asymptotes) to graph polynomial, rational, and radical equations in two variables
Use properties (e.g., symmetry, tangents at the origin, excluded values, intercepts) to graph polar equations
Use addition of ordinates to graph sums and differences of functions
Standard 10: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: SYMBOLIC REPRESENTATION—Use symbolic forms to represent, model, and analyze mathematical situations
NUMERIC AND ALGEBRAIC REPRESENTATION
Explain that a vector equation can represent a plane
Translate between parametric representations of curves and equations using rectangular coordinates
Use the concept of the distance from a point to a plane, distance between points, and the angle between two planes in three-dimensions to solve problems
Determine the intersection of polar equations algebraically and graphically, including using graphing technology when available
Convert between parametric equations and their graphs
Determine the intersection of curves algebraically and graphically, including using graphing technology when available
Standard 11: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: FLUENCY WITH DATA—Pose questions and collect, organize, and represent data to answer those questions
Standard 12: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: STATISTICS—Interpret data using methods of exploratory data analysis
Standard 13: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: DATA ANALYSIS—Develop and evaluate inferences, predictions, and arguments that are based on data
Standard 14: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: PROBABILITY—Understand and apply basic notions of chance and probability

text: Probability

children.text: Standard 1: Numbers and Operations: NUMBER SENSE—Understand numbers, ways of representing numbers, relationships among numbers, and number systems
Standard 2: Numbers and Operations: OPERATION SENSE—Understand the meaning of operations and how they relate to each other
Standard 3: Numbers and Operations: COMPUTATION STRATEGIES—Use computational tools and strategies fluently and, when appropriate, use estimation
Standard 4: Measurement: FLUENCY WITH MEASUREMENT—Understand attributes, units, and systems of units in measurement; and develop and use techniques, tools, and formulas for measuring
Standard 5: Geometry and Spatial Sense: PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS—Analyze properties of objects and relationships among the properties
Standard 6: Geometry and Spatial Sense: TRANSFORMATIONS AND SYMMETRY—Use transformations and symmetry to analyze mathematical situations
Standard 7: Geometry and Spatial Sense: VISUAL AND SPATIAL SENSE—Use visualization and spatial reasoning to solve problems both within and outside of mathematics
Standard 8: Geometry and Spatial Sense: REPRESENTATIONAL SYSTEMS—Select and use different representational systems, including coordinate geometry
Standard 9: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: PATTERNS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS—Understand various types of patterns and functional relationships
Standard 10: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: SYMBOLIC REPRESENTATION—Use symbolic forms to represent, model, and analyze mathematical situations
Standard 11: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: FLUENCY WITH DATA—Pose questions and collect, organize, and represent data to answer those questions
Standard 12: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: STATISTICS—Interpret data using methods of exploratory data analysis
Standard 13: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: DATA ANALYSIS—Develop and evaluate inferences, predictions, and arguments that are based on data
Standard 14: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: PROBABILITY—Understand and apply basic notions of chance and probability
PROBABILITY
Describe the relationship among events (e.g., inclusive, disjoint, complementary, independent, dependent)
Calculate the probability of two events under union and intersection
Differentiate between theoretical and experimental probability
Explain the difference between probability and odds and convert from one to the other
Calculate the probability of an outcome for an experiment with and without replacement
Apply discrete random variables to solve for the probability of experimental outcomes
Estimate and calculate expected values
Apply permutations, combinations, and the fundamental counting principle to calculate the probability of two events

text: Statistics

children.text: Standard 1: Numbers and Operations: NUMBER SENSE—Understand numbers, ways of representing numbers, relationships among numbers, and number systems
Standard 2: Numbers and Operations: OPERATION SENSE—Understand the meaning of operations and how they relate to each other
Standard 3: Numbers and Operations: COMPUTATION STRATEGIES—Use computational tools and strategies fluently and, when appropriate, use estimation
Standard 4: Measurement: FLUENCY WITH MEASUREMENT—Understand attributes, units, and systems of units in measurement; and develop and use techniques, tools, and formulas for measuring
Standard 5: Geometry and Spatial Sense: PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS—Analyze properties of objects and relationships among the properties
Standard 6: Geometry and Spatial Sense: TRANSFORMATIONS AND SYMMETRY—Use transformations and symmetry to analyze mathematical situations
Standard 7: Geometry and Spatial Sense: VISUAL AND SPATIAL SENSE—Use visualization and spatial reasoning to solve problems both within and outside of mathematics
Standard 8: Geometry and Spatial Sense: REPRESENTATIONAL SYSTEMS—Select and use different representational systems, including coordinate geometry
Standard 9: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: PATTERNS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS—Understand various types of patterns and functional relationships
Standard 10: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: SYMBOLIC REPRESENTATION—Use symbolic forms to represent, model, and analyze mathematical situations
Standard 11: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: FLUENCY WITH DATA—Pose questions and collect, organize, and represent data to answer those questions
DATA COLLECTION AND DISPLAY
Develop a hypothesis for an investigation or experiment
Recognize the variables and controls in an experiment or investigation
Select appropriate display for a data set (e.g., frequency table, histogram, line graph, bar graph, stem-and-leaf plot, box-andwhisker plot, scatter plot)
Recognize features of representations of data that can produce misleading interpretations
Recognize sampling, randomness, bias, and sampling size in data collection and interpretation
Describe the purpose and function of a variety of data collection methods (e.g., census, sample surveys, experiment, observation)
Standard 12: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: STATISTICS—Interpret data using methods of exploratory data analysis
DATA INTERPRETATION
Use measures of central tendency and spread to interpret data
Interpret data based on the correlation coefficient of two variables
Describe the effect of sample size and transformation on the shape, center, and spread of data
Use the line or curve of best fit to interpret data
Standard 13: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: DATA ANALYSIS—Develop and evaluate inferences, predictions, and arguments that are based on data
PREDICTIONS AND INFERENCES
Recognize that some data can be represented algebraically (e.g., linear, quadratic, exponential, sinusoidal)
Use interpolation and extrapolation to make predictions and inferences about data
Standard 14: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: PROBABILITY—Understand and apply basic notions of chance and probability

text: Calculus

children.text: Standard 1: Numbers and Operations: NUMBER SENSE—Understand numbers, ways of representing numbers, relationships among numbers, and number systems
Standard 2: Numbers and Operations: OPERATION SENSE—Understand the meaning of operations and how they relate to each other
Standard 3: Numbers and Operations: COMPUTATION STRATEGIES—Use computational tools and strategies fluently and, when appropriate, use estimation
Standard 4: Measurement: FLUENCY WITH MEASUREMENT—Understand attributes, units, and systems of units in measurement; and develop and use techniques, tools, and formulas for measuring
Standard 5: Geometry and Spatial Sense: PROPERTIES AND RELATIONSHIPS—Analyze properties of objects and relationships among the properties
Standard 6: Geometry and Spatial Sense: TRANSFORMATIONS AND SYMMETRY—Use transformations and symmetry to analyze mathematical situations
Standard 7: Geometry and Spatial Sense: VISUAL AND SPATIAL SENSE—Use visualization and spatial reasoning to solve problems both within and outside of mathematics
Standard 8: Geometry and Spatial Sense: REPRESENTATIONAL SYSTEMS—Select and use different representational systems, including coordinate geometry
Standard 9: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: PATTERNS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS—Understand various types of patterns and functional relationships
FUNCTION
Find the derivatives of functions, including polynomial, rational, trigonometric, logarithmic, inverse, composite, and exponential functions
Find the derivatives of implicitly-defined functions
Find points of inflection of functions
Use implicit differentiation to find the derivative of an inverse function
Use integration by substitution (or change of variable) to evaluate integrals
Use Riemann sums, the trapezoidal rule, and technology to approximate definite integrals of functions represented algebraically, geometrically, or by tables of values

Find specific antiderivatives using initial conditions, including finding velocity functions from acceleration functions, finding position functions from velocity functions, and applications to motion along a line
Use definite integrals to find the area between a curve and the x-axis, the average value of a function over a closed interval, and the volume of a solid with known cross-sectional area
Standard 10: Patterns, Functions, and Algebra: SYMBOLIC REPRESENTATION—Use symbolic forms to represent, model, and analyze mathematical situations
NUMERIC AND ALGEBRAIC REPRESENTATIONS
Recognize limits from graphs and tables
Find limits of sums, differences, products, quotients, and rational functions
Understand continuity in terms of limits and functions
Apply the intermediate value theorem and extreme value theorem on a function over a closed interval

Apply the fundamental theorem of calculus; i.e., interpret a definite integral of the rate of change of a quantity over an interval as the change of the quantity over the interval, that is ∫ f '(x)dx = f(b) – f(a)
Use the properties of definite integrals
RATES OF CHANGE
Describe the concept of a derivative geometrically, numerically, analytically, and verbally
Find second derivatives and derivatives of higher order
Prove the mean value theorem
Find average and instantaneous rates of change
Use first and second derivatives to describe the behavior of functions
Standard 11: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: FLUENCY WITH DATA—Pose questions and collect, organize, and represent data to answer those questions
Standard 12: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: STATISTICS—Interpret data using methods of exploratory data analysis
Standard 13: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: DATA ANALYSIS—Develop and evaluate inferences, predictions, and arguments that are based on data
Standard 14: Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: PROBABILITY—Understand and apply basic notions of chance and probability
